In fact, the complexity of the contemporary urban environments suggests the need to develop new surveillance tools to replace the current methods, which date back to 80 years ago. A tool commonly used to monitor and control Aedes is the oviposition traps or ovitraps,
14 which have been shown to be more sensitive than searching for larvae and/or pupae that can be spread in a wide range of cryptic breeding sites. In recent years, various traps for capturing Aedes adults and/or eggs have been described.

17 Studies using traps to monitor Aedes populations in several Brazilian cities have revealed high levels of infestation in urban spaces, and reproductively active females were present in more than 60% of the properties fitted with either traps for catching egg-laying females or with ovitraps.
18 A longitudinal study of Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus sympatric populations in seven of the 94 neighbourhoods of Recife city (Brazil), carried out by our group in 2003-2005 based on a network of 465 ovitraps, recorded broad and intensive Aedes presence in all neighbourhoods.
18 The overall infestation index was 98.5% and densities from 100 to 2500 eggs/ovitrap/month were recorded throughout the year, regardless of the different environmental and socio-economic conditions of those neighbourhoods.
